channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-9116] Add a view/edit tool for favored node mappings for regions
item.description: Add a tool that one can run offline to view the favored node mappings for regions, and also fix the mappings if needed. Such a tool exists in the 0.89-fb branch. Will port it over to trunk/0.95.
item.summary: Add a view/edit tool for favored node mappings for regions

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This is WIP, untested patch. Mostly a rebase of 0.89's code for the said tool.
This is the right one (deleted the earlier patch from jira).

Useful tool 


+    List<Float> dispersion = report.getDispersionInformation();

+    if (simplePrint) {

+      DecimalFormat df = new java.text.DecimalFormat("#.##");

+      System.out.println("\tAvg dispersion score: "

+          + df.format(dispersion.get(0)) + " hosts;\tMax dispersion score: "

It would be easier to maintain the code if index to dispersions has corresponding enum.

For FSRegionScanner :


+   * Maps region encoded names to maps of hostnames to fractional locality of

+   * that region on that host.

+   */

+  private Map<String, Map<String, Float>> regionDegreeLocalityMapping;

Should ServerName be used as key for the inner Map above ?


+        // not part of a table?

+        if (parent.getName().startsWith(".")

+            && !parent.getName().equals(".META.")) {

The above would need adjustment once namespace patch goes in.

RegionPlacementMaintainer.java needs license


+   * @param newPlanMap - new AssignmentPlan

+   * @return how many primaries will move per table

+   */

+  public Map<String, Integer> getRegionsMovement(FavoredNodes newPlan)

Parameter and its javadoc don't seem to match.

This looks like it needs rebased onto trunk.

The posted patch includes generated code (AdminProtos.java), please remove.

Please add javadoc for the new classes and new public methods on existing classes.

FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper#placeSecondaryAndTertiaryWithRestrictions introduces a while(true) block containing non-trivial branching logic. Can this be refactored with simpler and/or clearer break conditions?

FSUtils introduces new configuration hbase.client.localityCheck.threadPoolSize. Can this be added to HConstants and/or documented in hbase-defaults.xml?
This patch addresses most of the comments. Also, it implements the FavoredNodeLoadBalancer.balanceCluster method, that would do balancing solely on the favored nodes information.
Nudging hadoopqa a bit.
Not sure why hadoopqa is not picking this up. Retrying..

http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12599628/9116-2.txt
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 6 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

Fixes the hadoopqa warnings and unit tests.

+    for (ServerName sn: serverMgr.getOnlineServersList()) {

+      serverNameToServerNameWithoutCode.put(sn,

+          new ServerName(sn.getHostname(), sn.getPort(), ServerName.NON_STARTCODE));

+      serverNameWithoutCodeToServerName.put(

+          new ServerName(sn.getHostname(), sn.getPort(), ServerName.NON_STARTCODE), sn);

+    }

ServerName for (sn.getHostname(), sn.getPort(), ServerName.NON_STARTCODE) can be created first, avoiding an extra instantiation.


+        List<ServerName> favoredNodes = globalFavoredNodesAssignmentPlan.getFavoredNodes(region);

+        if (favoredNodes.get(0).equals(currentServerWithoutStartCode)) {

Is it possible that favoredNodes is null ?

I haven't run the tool, just read the code.
Seems ok, some nits:

long startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();

Please use EnvironmentEdge

* Copyright 2011 The Apache Software Foundation

No date anymore on licenses

// TODO Auto-generated method stub

Should be removed if we're fine with the standard generation

This message is automatically generated.
Added tests for verifying assignment when RSs are lost (regions for which this RS was primary should move to the secondaries).
lgtm

Why updateFavoredNodes takes an OpenRegionRequest? 

+  public UpdateFavoredNodesResponse updateFavoredNodes(RpcController controller,

+      OpenRegionRequest request) throws ServiceException {
Is the hbase-site.xml change intentional?

Can we create a similar putsToMetaTable method which takes a conf in MetaEditor? We need to handle exceptions and close the table at the end.

-    MetaEditor.putsToMetaTable(catalogTracker, puts);

+    // Write the region assignments to the meta table.

+    HTable metaTable = new HTable(conf, TableName.META_TABLE_NAME);

+    metaTable.put(puts);

I see several places warning is logged like this:

+        LOG.warn("Cannot place the favored nodes for region "

+            + regionInfo.getRegionNameAsString() + " because " + e);

Perhaps, it is better to log the stack trace as well:

+        LOG.warn("Cannot place the favored nodes for region "

+            + regionInfo.getRegionNameAsString() + " because " + e, e);

Some function may not throw exception declared, for example, FavoredNodeAssignmentHelper#placeSecondaryAndTertiaryWithRestrictions doesn't throw IOException.

Good stuff. Is this still WIP? How can we use this? Edit the meta table from hbase shell?

Sorry for the delay in responding. I couldn't get to it until now. Attached patch takes care of the comments.

Why updateFavoredNodes takes an OpenRegionRequest?

That's because the argument serves all the purpose of what is needed in the updateFavoredNodes RPC. I am open to defining a new argument if you think that'd be better.

Is the hbase-site.xml change intentional?

Nope. Accidental..

Can we create a similar putsToMetaTable method which takes a conf in MetaEditor? We need to handle exceptions and close the table at the end.

Done (added close)

Perhaps, it is better to log the stack trace as well

Done.

Some function may not throw exception declared

Fixed.

Good stuff. Is this still WIP? How can we use this? Edit the meta table from hbase shell?

This is mostly complete. It needs more real life testing. The RegionPlacementMaintainer in the patch has the commands to update meta (can be run like a regular Java app). That's the tool added (which is the majority of the code in this patch).

Is there a reason for SnapshotOfRegionAssignmentFromMeta to separate construction from initialization? Why not just call initialize() at the end of the constructor body?

Is it worth RegionPlacementMaintainer extending AbstractHBaseTool?

Is this necessary – can you instead separate out "case 2" as a second test?

-  @Test(timeout = 180000)

+  @Test(timeout = 1800000)

   public void testRegionPlacement() throws Exception {

FYI, it looks like this patch has some noise in it:

This message is automatically generated.

Why not just call initialize() at the end of the constructor body?

The reason being I wanted to keep the construction of the object cheap. The initialization does some IO since it scans the meta, and I wanted to keep this out of the basic constructor...

Is it worth RegionPlacementMaintainer extending AbstractHBaseTool?

IMHO this is not going to add that much value. Do you mind if I look at this in a follow up.

Is this necessary – can you instead separate out "case 2" as a second test?

-@Test(timeout = 180000)
+@Test(timeout = 1800000)

Fixed the timeout (that was a good catch). The reason the test is clubbed into one is that the test tries out the various favorednode utilities with a single table that it creates in the beginning.
The patch with the findbugs warnings taken care of, and one of Nick's comment addressed.

This message is automatically generated.

Overall +1. Everything below are just nits.

—

IMHO this is not going to add that much value. Do you mind if I look at this in a follow up.

No problem. I don't thing AbstractHBaseTool is used very often within the codebase anyway.

Fixed the timeout (that was a good catch). The reason the test is clubbed into one is that the test tries out the various favorednode utilities with a single table that it creates in the beginning.

I prefer independent tests to run in isolation of each other when at all possible. Not a show-stopper for the patch – I regard tweaking test timeouts as a kind of code smell.

+  <Match>

+    <!--

+     The logic explicitly checks equality of two floating point numbers. Ignore the warning

+    !-->

+    <Class name="org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.AssignmentVerificationReport"/>

+    <Bug pattern="FE_FLOATING_POINT_EQUALITY"/>

+  </Match>

AssignmentVerificationReport has separate logic blocks for floating point if (A > B) else if (A == B) – I wonder if this will be a future source of bugs.

You already defined UpdateFavoredNodesRequest, why not use it? These two calls may divert later on. It is better to use different message so that it will be easier to maintain compatibility.

Why does this one take a RegionOpenInfo? At least, it doesn't need the zk node version right?

+message UpdateFavoredNodesRequest {

+  repeated OpenRegionRequest.RegionOpenInfo updateRegionInfo = 1;

+}

Thanks, Nick.

I regard tweaking test timeouts as a kind of code smell.

I had increased the timeout so I could debug various things from within eclipse without the test timing out on me. The timeout annotation in the new patch is 3 minutes (which is what it was set to earlier) but I could actually remove that timeout annotation altogether on commit. The test runs in less than 2 minutes consistently..

AssignmentVerificationReport has separate logic blocks for floating point if (A > B) else if (A == B) – I wonder if this will be a future source of bugs.

I inspected that part some. The logic for reporting the max/min dispersion is built around the check for equality. This is used only for reporting purposes and we can tune this later if needed.

You already defined UpdateFavoredNodesRequest, why not use it?

Hmm. I had defined it and not used it...

I will do the needful for using UpdateFavoredNodesRequest in my next patch...
Patch that uses UpdateFavoredNodesRequest.
+1. Looks good to me.
